channel.title: Dualbooting Linux
channel.description:
Got MITB's attention. :)
Anyway, I have been wanting to try out Linux. So I decided I should dualboot it on my windows 7 machine, and I'm kinda stuck. :( So I have been watching tutorials on how to dualboot it, and they tell me to go to ubuntu.com and click on the 'Run with Windows' button. It then tells me to download a file called Wubi. So I download that, place it on my desktop, I run it, and I get this error:
[IMG]http://i.imgur.com/TTlB3.png[/img]
Everytime I close out of that box, hit cancel, hit try again, or hit continue, it just reappears. I know how to get rid of the message, but it just shows up again the next time I try and run Wubi.
Any help? Or am I doing this completely wrong?

@MrJasonStar wrote:

Sometimes I get a much faster download speed when I use wget to download from an FTP location. Torrenting doesn't work because my ISP throttle BitTorrent somehow.
I clap eyes on many good subjects about "General Discussion" are discussed at www.moparcraft.net. As i want to express that i seen your blog rather usefull, it helped me understand this issue in front of you greatly. I would prefer to know if i can create articles and reviews for a weblog. At the same time I would suggest to review this website - -snip-

Read full topic

item.title: Dualbooting Linux
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

The biggest problem people have with installing GRUB is that they install it to a partition, and not to the drive itself. So basically, they do

grub-install /dev/sda1

instead of just

grub-install /dev/sda

Read full topic

item.title: Dualbooting Linux
item.dc:creator: @zuppers zuppers
item.description:
@zuppers wrote:

[quote=“Travas, post:34, topic:411946”][quote author=zuppers link=topic=513204.msg3729430#msg3729430 date=1314512469]
http://homesupport.cisco.com/en-us/wireless/lbc/WUSB600N
This is what your looking for, check under downloads.
[/quote]
Alright, so I download that. Next, do I place it on my USB and transfer it to Ubuntu, and follow the rest of this?:

[quote]
Install ndisgtk (System → Administration → Synaptic Package Manager).

Open ndisgtk (System → Administration → Windows Wireless Drivers).

Select Install new driver.

Choose the location of your Windows .inf file and click Install.

Click OK.[/quote][/quote]Yup.

Read full topic

[quote=“zuppers, post:33, topic:411946”]http://homesupport.cisco.com/en-us/wireless/lbc/WUSB600N
This is what your looking for, check under downloads.[/quote]
Alright, so I download that. Next, do I place it on my USB and transfer it to Ubuntu, and follow the rest of this?:

Install ndisgtk (System → Administration → Synaptic Package Manager).

Open ndisgtk (System → Administration → Windows Wireless Drivers).

Select Install new driver.

Choose the location of your Windows .inf file and click Install.

Click OK.

Click OK.[/quote]

[/quote]You need to download the windows version driver of your wireless.[/quote]
I can’t find a download for it, I don’t even know if I’m looking at the right thing

VlTtA.png791×573

item.title: Dualbooting Linux
item.dc:creator: @zuppers zuppers
item.description:
@zuppers wrote:

[quote=“Travas, post:28, topic:411946”][quote author=zuppers link=topic=513204.msg3728815#msg3728815 date=1314477968]

[quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=513204.msg3728545#msg3728545 date=1314467262]

Well, I am now successfully dual-booting Windows 7 and Ubuntu. I absolutely love Ubuntu, I wish I would have did this a long time ago.

Now, how come it won’t let me connect to the internet?
[/quote]Over wireless? If you’re lucky you can just install the third party drivers from the networking drop-down menu. I think you can also get to the same thing from System->Administration iirc.
[/quote]I had to use ndiswrapper.

What’s that?[/quote]
https://help.ubuntu.com/8.04/internet/C/ndiswrapper.html

Read full topic

[quote=“Travas, post:23, topic:411946”]Alright, I’m gonna start torrenting it. Does it matter if it’s 32 or 64 bit?[/quote]If your hardware is 64 bit capable and you have more than 4gb of ram installed I’d suggest 64bit. Otherwise 32.

item.title: Dualbooting Linux
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

Alright, I’m gonna start torrenting it. Does it matter if it’s 32 or 64 bit? Also, I know this one’s not the most updated one, but this is the one I’m gonna download: http://thepiratebay.org/torrent/5520252/Ubuntu_10.04_LTS_x32

xx matty xx:

Anyway, it’s probably a good idea to just check the hash on your download. Just to make sure corruption is the problem here.

How would I do that?

Read full topic

item.title: Dualbooting Linux
item.dc:creator: @xx_matty_xx Justin Bieber
item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Yeah, it doesn’t really make sense that the same file would always corrupt. Maybe the actual corruption can be anywhere, but the problem just appears to be in filesystem.squashfs?

Downloading over wireless rather than ethernet can cause corruption because of interference and packet loss etc. I remember when I was trying to direct-download a disc image for something a while ago, and it corrupted every time. Torrents are much more reliable because the protocol is pretty much built around hash checks. So I’d suggest either torrenting over wireless, or direct-downloading over ethernet.

Anyway, it’s probably a good idea to just check the hash on your download. Just to make sure corruption is the problem here…

Read full topic

item.title: Dualbooting Linux
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

Yes, it is a file and it seems to me I’m not the only one having a problem. http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1654139
Read the last post on the link, he/she said that they had to be plugged into Ethernet and redownload, but I can’t really imagine why having a wireless connection would cause a file ([font=verdana][size=11px]filesystem.squashfs) to corrupt. [/size][/font]

[font=verdana][size=11px]EDIT: Now I get no errors when putting the files on the USB, but when I reboot and start up Ubuntu, i get this:[/size][/font]
[font=verdana][/font]

[font=verdana][/font][font=Verdana]size=12px mount: mounting /dev/loop0 on //filesystem.squashfs failed: invalid argument[/size][/font][font=Verdana][/size][size=12px]
Can not mount /dev/loop0 (/cdrom/casper/filesystem.squashfs) on //filesystem.squashfs[/size][/font]
[font=Verdana][/font]

Read full topic

I’d download the file for you, but it sounds like my internet is just as slow as yours. Besides, you don’t know what other files have corrupted (is filesystem.squashfs even a file?!).

Read full topic

item.description:

Hashes?

Is it possible someone could just upload the ‘[font=verdana][size=11px]filesystem.squashfs’ file and I could replace it? And yes, I used a direct download[/size][/font]

item.description:
@xx_matty_xx wrote:

Yeah, probably corrupt. Did you torrent it or direct download? Next time check the hashes to make sure it didn’t corrupt. (or check this versions hashes if you still have the file)

item.title: Dualbooting Linux
item.dc:creator: @Travas Travas
item.description:
@Travas wrote:

I’m having a problem.

Every time I put everything onto my USB like I’m supposed to, I get this: “Data error in ‘casper\filesystem.squashfs’. File is broken.”
I’m guessing it’s corrupt and I have to download the 700MB file again.

So then when I reboot my computer Ubuntu throws a shitload of errors.

Read full topic

item.title: Dualbooting Linux
item.dc:creator: @zuppers zuppers
item.description:
@zuppers wrote:

[quote=“HcoJustin, post:15, topic:411946”][quote author=zuppers link=topic=513204.msg3727084#msg3727084 date=1314337942]

wjexwy.png787×535

sda1 is my ubuntu installation. I set it as boot and couldn’t even boot into it. Operating system not found. This probably has something todo with windows (vista) over writing the boot-loader.
I installed grub on my live cd session but I don’t think I can fix my mbr using that.

EDIT: I’ve tried using Boot-Repair but all that did was break my windows booting capability. So now all I can do is boot from the live-cd.

EDIT EDIT: I tried Boot-Repair again except this time did a custom purge and install of grub and managed to get it to list my linux distributions and vista on the bootloader. What a pain in the ass.
[/quote]

What was the problem the first time? Unless an error occurred during the installation, it should handle installing GRUB and properly setting up all the flags for the partitions. If you manually set the boot flag that could have been the problem.[/quote]I’m guessing there must have been some sort of error with where it choose to install grub. Before I think it tried to install it to sda1 but the second time I was able to tell it to install to sda.

And yea everything seems to be fixed.

Read full topic

item.title: Dualbooting Linux
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

[quote=“zuppers, post:13, topic:411946”]

wjexwy.png787×535

sda1 is my ubuntu installation. I set it as boot and couldn’t even boot into it. Operating system not found. This probably has something todo with windows (vista) over writing the boot-loader.
I installed grub on my live cd session but I don’t think I can fix my mbr using that.

EDIT: I’ve tried using Boot-Repair but all that did was break my windows booting capability. So now all I can do is boot from the live-cd.

EDIT EDIT: I tried Boot-Repair again except this time did a custom purge and install of grub and managed to get it to list my linux distributions and vista on the bootloader. What a pain in the ass.[/quote]

What was the problem the first time? Unless an error occurred during the installation, it should handle installing GRUB and properly setting up all the flags for the partitions. If you manually set the boot flag that could have been the problem.

Read full topic

item.title: Dualbooting Linux
item.dc:creator: @zuppers zuppers
item.description:
@zuppers wrote:

wjexwy.png787×535

sda1 is my ubuntu installation. I set it as boot and couldn’t even boot into it. Operating system not found. This probably has something todo with windows (vista) over writing the boot-loader.
I installed grub on my live cd session but I don’t think I can fix my mbr using that.

EDIT: I’ve tried using Boot-Repair but all that did was break my windows booting capability. So now all I can do is boot from the live-cd.

EDIT EDIT: I tried Boot-Repair again except this time did a custom purge and install of grub and managed to get it to list my linux distributions and vista on the bootloader. What a pain in the ass.

Read full topic
